questions.question: What is the primary focus of Software Engineering compared to traditional programming?
options: Following structured processes and ensuring quality throughout the software lifecycle
questions.correct_answer: Following structured processes and ensuring quality throughout the software lifecycle

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT a common cause of the Software Crisis (1960s-1990s)?
questions.correct_answer: Lack of programming languages

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a feasibility study in software development?
options: To write the code for the system
To decide whether the project should be built
To deploy the software to users
questions.correct_answer: To decide whether the project should be built

questions.question: Which type of feasibility study examines whether the system complies with laws and regulations like GDPR?
questions.correct_answer: Legal Feasibility

questions.question: What is the correct sequence of SDLC phases?
options: Design → Requirements → Implementation → Testing → Deployment → Maintenance
Requirements → Design → Implementation → Testing → Deployment → Maintenance
Implementation → Design → Requirements → Testing → Deployment → Maintenance
Requirements → Implementation → Design → Testing → Deployment → Maintenance
questions.correct_answer: Requirements → Design → Implementation → Testing → Deployment → Maintenance

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a functional requirement?
options: The system should load within 3 seconds
The system should allow users to log in
The system must run on Android only
The system should be accessible on mobile devices
questions.correct_answer: The system should allow users to log in

questions.question: What type of requirement is 'The system should be accessible on both desktop and mobile devices'?
questions.correct_answer: Non-functional requirement

questions.question: Which requirement gathering technique involves observing users performing their daily work?
questions.correct_answer: Observations

questions.question: What is a stakeholder in software engineering?
options: Only the people who fund the project
Only the end users of the system
Any person or group who has an interest in the software system
questions.correct_answer: Any person or group who has an interest in the software system

questions.question: What happens during the System Design phase of SDLC?
options: Translating requirements into a system blueprint including UI design and database schema
questions.correct_answer: Translating requirements into a system blueprint including UI design and database schema

questions.question: What type of testing checks if each small piece of code works correctly on its own?
questions.correct_answer: Unit Testing

questions.question: Which type of maintenance fixes bugs or errors found after the system is deployed?
questions.correct_answer: Corrective Maintenance

questions.question: What is the main difference between Software Engineering and Programming?
options: SE uses different programming languages than programming
SE is process-driven and covers the entire software lifecycle, while programming focuses mainly on coding
SE is only for large companies, programming is for individuals
SE doesn't involve any coding activities
questions.correct_answer: SE is process-driven and covers the entire software lifecycle, while programming focuses mainly on coding

questions.question: Which organization created the joint Software Engineering Code of Ethics specifically for software engineers?
questions.correct_answer: IEEE and ACM together

questions.question: What is the purpose of Acceptance Testing?
options: To check if individual modules work correctly
To verify that different modules work well together
To test the whole system behavior
To check if the system meets the client's requirements
questions.correct_answer: To check if the system meets the client's requirements

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT typically included in the Deployment phase?
options: Installing software in the real environment
questions.correct_answer: Writing the actual code

questions.question: What is Operational Feasibility concerned with?
options: Whether the technology exists to build the system
Whether the project is financially viable
Whether users will actually use the system
Whether the project can be completed on time
questions.correct_answer: Whether users will actually use the system

questions.question: Which of the following is a key ethical principle in Software Engineering?
options: Protecting users' personal information and privacy
Using the most complex technology available
Completing projects as quickly as possible
questions.correct_answer: Protecting users' personal information and privacy

questions.question: What is the output of the Requirements Gathering phase?
questions.correct_answer: Software Requirements Specification (SRS)

questions.question: Which software failure was caused by a missing hyphen in the code?
questions.correct_answer: Mariner 1 (NASA)

questions.question: What is the primary difference between SDLC and Software Process Models?
options: SDLC defines what phases to follow, while Software Process Models define how to execute those phases
SDLC is for large projects, while Software Process Models are for small projects
SDLC is outdated, while Software Process Models are modern
SDLC and Software Process Models are the same thing
questions.answer: SDLC defines what phases to follow, while Software Process Models define how to execute those phases

questions.question: Which software process model follows a linear and step-by-step approach where each phase is completed before moving to the next?
What is the main advantage of the Iterative Waterfall Model over the traditional Waterfall Model?
options: It allows feedback and revisions between phases
questions.answer: It allows feedback and revisions between phases

questions.question: Which model is most suitable for safety-critical systems like medical devices and automotive systems?
In the V-Model, what does the 'V' shape represent?
options: Development on the left side and testing/validation on the right side
questions.answer: Development on the left side and testing/validation on the right side

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Prototyping Model?
options: To build a quick and rough version to show users early and get feedback
To eliminate the need for testing
To speed up the coding phase
questions.answer: To build a quick and rough version to show users early and get feedback

questions.question: Which model delivers software in small functional units called increments?
What are the four main phases in each spiral loop of the Spiral Model?
Which model is most appropriate for high-risk, large-scale projects with changing requirements?
What is the typical duration of a sprint in Agile/Scrum methodology?
Which Agile framework focuses on visualizing tasks on a board and managing continuous flow of work?
What are the three key roles in Scrum?
When should the Waterfall Model be used?
options: When requirements are unclear and may change frequently
When the project is high-risk and complex
When requirements are clearly known in advance and unlikely to change
When rapid delivery is the top priority
questions.answer: When requirements are clearly known in advance and unlikely to change

questions.question: Which model combines features of both Waterfall and Prototyping models?
What is the main focus of the Agile methodology?
options: Team collaboration, customer feedback, and flexibility to change
questions.answer: Team collaboration, customer feedback, and flexibility to change

questions.question: In which year was the Agile Manifesto created?
Which model is best suited for projects where requirements may change frequently and fast delivery is important?
What type of relationship does inheritance represent in the context of software development models?
options: Each model inherits from previous models
Models build upon lessons learned from earlier approaches
questions.answer: Models build upon lessons learned from earlier approaches

questions.question: Which factor is most important when choosing between different software process models?
options: The programming language to be used
The size of the development team

questions.question: For a COVID-19 vaccination appointment system that needs rapid deployment, which model would be most appropriate?
What are the 4 key values of the Agile Manifesto?
options: Individuals and Interactions, Working Software, Customer Collaboration, Responding to Change
questions.answer: Individuals and Interactions, Working Software, Customer Collaboration, Responding to Change

questions.question: In Agile methodology, what is prioritized over 'Comprehensive Documentation'?
Who is responsible for deciding which features and functionalities to build in SCRUM?
What is the maximum duration of a Sprint in SCRUM?
What is the correct template for writing User Stories?
options: As a <user role> I want to <goal> So that <benefit>
questions.answer: As a <user role> I want to <goal> So that <benefit>

questions.question: Which SCRUM role has no authority to exert control over the development team?
What is a Product Backlog?
options: A prioritized list of work for the development team from product plan and requirements
A list of bugs found during testing
questions.answer: A prioritized list of work for the development team from product plan and requirements

questions.question: Which characteristic is NOT associated with traditional software development methodologies?
What are the three main questions typically asked during Daily Scrum?
options: What will you do? When will you finish? Who will help?
What did you accomplish since last daily scrum? What will you work on? What impediments exist?
What is done? What is in progress? What is planned?
What worked? What didn't work? What should we improve?
questions.answer: What did you accomplish since last daily scrum? What will you work on? What impediments exist?

questions.question: What does a Sprint Burn Down Chart represent?
options: Work left to do vs time
questions.answer: Work left to do vs time

questions.question: Which SCRUM artifact is a subset of Product Backlog user stories defined for a particular sprint?
What is the primary purpose of Sprint Review?
options: To inspect the Increment and adapt the Product Backlog if needed
To assign new tasks to team members
To conduct a retrospective on team performance
questions.answer: To inspect the Increment and adapt the Product Backlog if needed

questions.question: What is the main purpose of Sprint Retrospective?
options: To review the product increment and get feedback from stakeholders
To plan the work for the next sprint and prioritize the product backlog
To inspect the team's performance and identify improvements for the next sprint
To coordinate work across multiple teams and align on product vision
questions.answer: To inspect the team's performance and identify improvements for the next sprint

questions.question: In the Product Backlog, where do high-value items appear?
options: At the bottom of the backlog
At the top of the product backlog
questions.answer: At the top of the product backlog

questions.question: What is the ideal burn down velocity if a project has 120 tasks to complete in 5 days?
Which of the following is NOT a SCRUM artifact?
What does 'Responding to Change' prioritize over in Agile values?
Which characteristic best describes the Development Team in SCRUM?
According to the lecture, why is Agile valuable for Computer Science and Network Engineering (CSNE) projects?
options: It eliminates the need for documentation
Its adaptability makes it valuable for complex network infrastructure projects
questions.answer: Its adaptability makes it valuable for complex network infrastructure projects

questions.question: What happens to the Product Backlog over the course of a project?
options: The Product backlog is a constantly evolving artifact
It is only updated at the end of each sprint
It is replaced with a new backlog each sprint
questions.answer: The Product backlog is a constantly evolving artifact

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a Use Case Model in software engineering?
options: To define how the system will be implemented
To graphically represent the proposed functionality of the new system
To show the database design of the system
questions.answer: To graphically represent the proposed functionality of the new system

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a basic component of a Use Case diagram?
What does an Actor represent in a Use Case diagram?
options: A function performed by the system
The roles adopted by those participating with the system
questions.answer: The roles adopted by those participating with the system

questions.question: What is the correct notation for representing an Actor in a Use Case diagram?
Which relationship indicates that an actor participates in a use case?
In an <<include>> relationship, which statement is correct?
options: The included use case can stand alone
The base use case explicitly incorporates the behavior of another use case
It represents inheritance between use cases
questions.answer: The base use case explicitly incorporates the behavior of another use case

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of an <<extend>> relationship?
options: The base use case cannot stand alone
The base use case may stand alone, but can be extended under certain conditions
questions.answer: The base use case may stand alone, but can be extended under certain conditions

questions.question: In actor generalization, what does the child actor inherit?
options: Only the name of the parent actor
Only the use cases of the parent actor
All characteristics and behavior of the parent actor
questions.answer: All characteristics and behavior of the parent actor

questions.question: What is the correct stereotype notation for an include relationship?
Which of the following best describes a Use Case?
options: A unit of behavior in the proposed system
questions.answer: A unit of behavior in the proposed system

questions.question: What does the System Boundary represent in a Use Case diagram?
options: The physical limits of the hardware
The boundary between the system and external actors
questions.answer: The boundary between the system and external actors

questions.question: Use case names typically follow which naming convention?
Which of the following is true about Use Case scenarios?
options: They define the specific sequence of events between system and actors
They are optional in use case modeling
They replace the use case diagram
questions.answer: They define the specific sequence of events between system and actors

questions.question: What should be included in the Main Success Scenario of a use case?
options: The happy path when everything goes as planned
questions.answer: The happy path when everything goes as planned

questions.question: In a use case specification, what are Extensions used for?
options: To describe the main flow only
To describe alternative paths and exceptional flows
questions.answer: To describe alternative paths and exceptional flows

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid precondition for a use case?
options: User has successfully completed the use case
User has logged into the system
questions.answer: User has logged into the system

questions.question: What distinguishes Use Case diagrams from other UML diagrams?
options: They focus on WHAT the system will do, not HOW
They are used only for testing
questions.answer: They focus on WHAT the system will do, not HOW

questions.question: In use case generalization, what happens to the child use case?
options: It replaces the parent use case completely
It inherits behavior and may add to or override the parent's behavior
It has no relationship to the parent
questions.answer: It inherits behavior and may add to or override the parent's behavior

questions.question: Which relationship type shows that one use case is a specialized version of another?
What is the main benefit of using Use Case modeling in requirements engineering?
options: It serves as an excellent communication tool with stakeholders about system functionality
It shows the system's internal structure
questions.answer: It serves as an excellent communication tool with stakeholders about system functionality

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of an Activity Diagram in UML?
options: To model static structure of classes
To model workflows and system behavior
To show object interactions over time
questions.answer: To model workflows and system behavior

questions.question: Which symbol represents the initial node in an Activity Diagram?
What does a decision node represent in an Activity Diagram?
Which element is used to show activities that can occur in parallel?
What shape is used to represent a decision node?
In Activity Diagrams, what does a fork node do?
options: Splits one flow into multiple parallel flows
questions.answer: Splits one flow into multiple parallel flows

questions.question: What is the relationship between fork and join nodes?
options: Every fork must have a corresponding join
questions.answer: Every fork must have a corresponding join

questions.question: Which notation indicates iteration in an Activity Diagram?
What is a swimlane used for in Activity Diagrams?
options: To partition activities by organizational units or actors
To mark the end of activities
questions.answer: To partition activities by organizational units or actors

questions.question: How is a sub-activity (call action) indicated in an Activity Diagram?
What does a merge node do in an Activity Diagram?
Which type of flow occurs at a fork node?
options: Control flows down only one path
Control flows down all forked paths
questions.answer: Control flows down all forked paths

questions.question: What must be specified for each branch coming out of a decision node?
Activity Diagrams are most similar to which programming construct?
What shape represents an action node in Activity Diagrams?
When should Activity Diagrams be used?
options: For modeling business processes and analyzing use cases
questions.answer: For modeling business processes and analyzing use cases

questions.question: What is the difference between a merge and a join?
options: No difference, they are the same
Merge combines alternative paths, join synchronizes parallel flows
Join combines alternative paths, merge synchronizes parallel flows
Merge is for decisions, join is for actions
questions.answer: Merge combines alternative paths, join synchronizes parallel flows

questions.question: How should text in action nodes be written?
options: As verb phrases in present tense
questions.answer: As verb phrases in present tense

questions.question: What represents the final node in an Activity Diagram?
Which element connects activities in an Activity Diagram?
